SystemOutput:
CHIEF COMPLAINT

Fatigue, lightheadedness, and occasional shortness of breath.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Brian is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for congestive heart failure and hypertension, who presents today for follow-up of his chronic problems. The patient reports feeling out of sorts for the past five weeks, experiencing fatigue, lightheadedness, and occasional shortness of breath. He denies fever, chills, nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea. The patient has been compliant with his medications and has been monitoring his blood pressure at home. He admits to struggling with his diet due to recent home renovations and eating out more frequently.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Endorses fatigue and lightheadedness. Denies fever and chills.
• Cardiovascular: Endorses occasional shortness of breath and slight chest cramps.
• Respiratory: Endorses a slight cough. Denies difficulty breathing.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea, vomiting, and diarrhea.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Jugular venous distention to 8 cm. 3/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Fine crackles at the bases bilaterally.
• Extremities: 1+ pitting edema in lower extremities.

RESULTS

Chest X-ray: Fluid in the lungs.
Echocardiogram (4 months ago): Pumping function reduced at 45%, mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Congestive heart failure.
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient is experiencing fatigue, lightheadedness, and occasional shortness of breath. Physical examination findings and chest X-ray suggest fluid retention.
   • Additional Testing: Order another echocardiogram.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase Lasix to 80 mg once a day. Instruct the patient to weigh himself daily and report any weight gain or worsening symptoms.
   
2. Hypertension.
   • Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood pressure is well-managed at this time.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Lisinopril 20 mg daily. Instruct the patient to continue monitoring blood pressure at home and report any elevations through the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female who presents with right knee pain after a fall from a ladder while changing a light bulb yesterday. She reports twisting her knee while trying to catch her fall. She denies any other injuries. The patient has been applying ice and taking ibuprofen, but reports minimal relief.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Atrial fibrillation.

CURRENT MEDICATIONS

Digoxin.

PAST SURGICAL HISTORY

Rhinoplasty.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Musculoskeletal: Right knee pain and tenderness.
• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or palpitations.
• Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Musculoskeletal: Tenderness over the medial portion of the right knee, specifically over the medial meniscus area. Pain with valgus stress. Normal sensation in the lower extremity.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm.
• Respiratory: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.

RESULTS
Imaging

X-ray of the right knee: No fractures or dislocations. Mild joint effusion noted.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Ms. Thompson is a 43-year-old female presenting with right knee pain after a fall.

Acute medial meniscus strain.
• Medical Reasoning: Tenderness over the medial meniscus area and pain with valgus stress on exam. X-ray shows no fractures or dislocations but mild joint effusion.
• Medical Treatment: Knee brace and crutches for the next couple of days. Follow up in one week. If not improved, consider MRI.
• Medication: Motrin 800 mg every six hours with food for two weeks.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Back pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Logan is a 58-year-old male with a past medical history significant for diabetes type 2, hypertension, osteoarthritis, who presents today with back pain. The patient reports lifting heavy boxes too quickly, resulting in a popping sound and subsequent pain in his lower back. This occurred on Saturday morning, and the patient has experienced stiffness since then. He has taken Tylenol and ibuprofen and used Icy Hot, but with minimal relief. He reports tingling in his right toes until Sunday afternoon, which has since resolved. Lying on his right side provides some relief.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Denies chest pain or dyspnea on exertion. Endorses a 2/6 systolic heart murmur.
• Respiratory: Denies shortness of breath.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies hematemesis, hematochezia, melena, heartburn, or abdominal pain.
• Genitourinary: Denies urinary urgency, pain, or incontinence.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses lower back pain.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Respiratory: Lungs are clear to auscultation bilaterally. No wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
• Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm. 2/6 systolic heart murmur. No extra heart sounds.
• Musculoskeletal: Pain to palpation of the lumbar spine. Pain with flexion and extension of the back. Negative straight leg raise.

RESULTS

X-ray of the lumbar spine is unremarkable. Normal bony alignment. No fractures were noted.

Labs: Hemoglobin A1C is elevated at 8.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Lumbar strain.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient reports lower back pain after lifting heavy boxes. X-ray of the lumbar spine is unremarkable.
   • Medical Treatment: Initiate meloxicam 15 mg once daily. Continue icing and avoiding strenuous activity.
   • Specialist Referrals: Refer to physical therapy.

2. Diabetes type 2.
   • Medical Reasoning: Hemoglobin A1C is elevated at 8.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase metformin to 1000 mg twice daily. Repeat hemoglobin A1C in 6 months.

3. Hypertension.
   • Medical Reasoning: Blood pressure readings are elevated.
   • Medical Treatment: Increase lisinopril from 10 mg to 20 mg daily.

4. Osteoarthritis.
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient is managing knee pain well.
   • Medical Treatment: No further workup needed at this time.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Annual exam.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Mr. Ralph is a 62-year-old male with a past medical history significant for depression, prior lobectomy, and hypertension, who presents for his annual exam. The patient reports a tough spring due to pollen allergies and some stress related to moving his daughter into college. He has been managing his depression with Prozac and reports no recent incidents. He has been struggling with hypertension and admits to occasionally forgetting to take his medication on weekends.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Denies fever, chills, or weight loss.
• Ears, Nose, Mouth, and Throat: Endorses nasal congestion from pollen allergies.
• Cardiovascular: Endorses shortness of breath with exertion (running 4-5 miles daily).
• Respiratory: Denies cough.
• Musculoskeletal: Denies muscle aches or lower extremity edema.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Slight 2/6 systolic ejection murmur.
• Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation.
• Musculoskeletal: No lower extremity edema.
• Head, Eyes, Ears, Nose, and Throat: Pain to palpation of sinuses.

RESULTS

EKG: Normal.
Chest X-ray: Normal, no concerning findings related to prior lobectomy.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Depression:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient reports doing well on Prozac 20 mg daily.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue Prozac 20 mg daily.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Encourage the patient to continue taking medication as prescribed and refill provided.

2. Prior lobectomy:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient reports no significant issues with breathing function and exercises regularly.
   • Medical Treatment: No further workup or follow-up with the surgeon needed at this time.

3. Hypertension:
   • Medical Reasoning: Patient's blood pressure is well-controlled in the office, but he admits to occasionally forgetting medication on weekends.
   • Medical Treatment: Continue current medication (Norvasc).
   • Additional Testing: Order an echocardiogram to evaluate the systolic ejection murmur.
   • Patient Education and Counseling: Encourage the patient to take medication consistently, even on weekends, and follow up with results through the patient portal.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right index finger pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Sharon Brooks is a 48-year-old female presenting with right index finger pain. The patient reports that she was skiing over the weekend and while going over moguls, her ski pole strap caught on her finger, causing it to bend back. The incident occurred on Sunday. She has tried icing the finger and taking ibuprofen, but the pain persists. The pain is worse with movement.

The patient also reports recent constipation, for which she has been taking Miralax.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Appendectomy at age 18.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Musculoskeletal: Endorses right index finger pain.
• Gastrointestinal: Endorses constipation.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Musculoskeletal: Tenderness over the distal phalanx of the right index finger. No tenderness over the proximal joint or metacarpophalangeal joint. Pain with flexion.

RESULTS

X-ray of the right index finger: No fractures, good alignment.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Sharon Brooks is a 48-year-old female presenting with right index finger pain after a skiing incident.

Right index finger contusion.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient's x-ray shows no fractures, and her physical exam reveals tenderness over the distal phalanx of the right index finger. The diagnosis is a right index finger contusion.
• Medical Treatment: Prescribe Motrin 600 mg every 6 hours for one week. Provide an aluminum foam splint for support.
• Patient Education and Counseling: Advise the patient to follow up if the pain does not improve within a week.

Constipation.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient reports recent constipation and is currently taking Miralax.
• Medical Treatment: Continue Miralax as needed.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Iron deficiency anemia.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient is a 65-year-old female who presents for evaluation of long-standing iron deficiency anemia. She was recently unable to donate blood due to her anemia. The patient has been dealing with anemia since she was 13 years old. She reports fatigue, feverish feelings with chills, shortness of breath, wheezing, and headaches. The patient also mentions increased anxiety and depression. She has been taking ferrous sulfate 25 mg twice daily and over-the-counter vitamin B12.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

The patient had a hysterectomy in 1996.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Positive for fatigue, feverish feelings, and chills.
• Respiratory: Positive for shortness of breath and wheezing.
• Neurological: Positive for headaches.
• Psychiatric: Positive for increased anxiety and depression.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General Examination: Patient appears well-nourished and in no acute distress.
• Cardiovascular: Heart sounds normal.
• Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
• Gastrointestinal: Abdomen soft, non-tender, and non-distended.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

The patient is a 65-year-old female who presents for evaluation of long-standing iron deficiency anemia.

Iron Deficiency Anemia
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has a history of anemia since she was 13 years old. She has been taking ferrous sulfate and vitamin B12. The cause of her anemia is still unclear.
• Additional Testing: Schedule upper endoscopy and colonoscopy to assess for potential sources of anemia or GI bleed. If inconclusive, consider capsule endoscopy.
• Referral: Send a referral to a hematologist for further evaluation and management.
• Medical Treatment: Continue taking ferrous sulfate 25 mg twice daily with orange juice for better absorption. Recheck CBC, iron, ferritin, B12, and folate in 8-12 weeks.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan and will schedule the necessary tests and appointments.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Worsening headaches and incidental pituitary lesion.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient is a 52-year-old male who presents for evaluation of worsening headaches over the past few months and a newly diagnosed pituitary lesion. The patient denies any history of headaches in the past. His past clinical history is unremarkable. The patient reports that the headaches are located behind his eyes and are described as a dull nagging ache. The onset was gradual, starting about three months ago, and has been worsening over time. The headaches are worse in the morning and last a few hours at a time. The patient denies any other associated symptoms such as fever, rash, neck stiffness, numbness, weakness, or passing out. However, he reports bumping into door frames recently.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Constitutional: Negative for fever, chills, or unintentional weight changes.
• Neurological: Positive for worsening headaches and bitemporal hemianopia.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Unremarkable.

FAMILY HISTORY

Unknown, patient was adopted.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient is a computer programmer, married for 25 years, and recently bought a small house. He denies any alcohol, smoking, or recreational drug use.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• General: Alert, oriented to time, place, and person. Affect is appropriate and speech is fluent.
• Neurological: Cranial nerve examination is grossly intact. No focal motor or sensory deficit in the upper or lower extremities. Visual acuity and eye movements are normal. Pupils are equal and reactive. Visual field testing reveals bitemporal hemianopia. Color vision is normal.

RESULTS
Imaging

MRI of the brain with contrast from 3/4/21 reveals a pituitary lesion with elevation and compression of the optic chiasm. The ventricles are normal in size and no other abnormalities are noted.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

The patient is a 52-year-old male with worsening headaches and an incidental pituitary lesion.

Pituitary Adenoma
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has clinical and radiographical evidence of optic chiasmal compression due to a pituitary lesion, likely a benign pituitary adenoma.
• Surgical Intervention: Transsphenoidal approach for excision and decompression of the pituitary fossa is indicated.
• Additional Testing: The patient will be referred for a visual field test and a full eye exam.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended surgical intervention plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Betty Hill is a 52-year-old female with a past medical history of uterine fibroids, anemia, and gallbladder removal. She presents today with a referral from the ER for esophagitis. The patient reports experiencing chest pain for four days in early October 2020. The pain was located in the center of her chest, behind her breastbone, and was sharp in nature. The pain was worse with eating and she had difficulty swallowing during that time. The patient went to the ER, where they performed an EKG and blood tests, which were normal. The chest pain and swallowing problem resolved three days after the ER visit.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Denies current chest pain.
• Gastrointestinal: Denies abdominal pain, normal bowel movements. Reports mild tenderness in the upper abdominal quadrants during physical examination.
• Musculoskeletal: Denies joint pain.
• Neurological: Denies headaches.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Cardiovascular: Normal heart sounds.
• Gastrointestinal: Mild tenderness to light palpation in the upper abdominal quadrants. No rebound tenderness or guarding.
• Musculoskeletal: Normal range of motion.
• Neurological: Alert and oriented.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Betty Hill is a 52-year-old female with a past medical history of uterine fibroids, anemia, and gallbladder removal. She presents today with a referral from the ER for esophagitis.

Possible etiologies:
• GERD
• Dyspepsia
• Esophagitis
• Musculoskeletal etiologies
• Anxiety

Suspected anxiety attack related to job transition, plus or minus a contribution from musculoskeletal etiologies.

• Medical Reasoning: The patient's chest pain and difficulty swallowing resolved three days after the ER visit, and she has been asymptomatic since then. The ER ruled out any heart issues, and the patient mentioned going through a stressful job transition around the time of the chest pain.
• Additional Testing: None at this time.
• Medical Treatment: Monitor for any additional symptoms.
• Patient Education and Counseling: The patient elected to self-monitor her symptoms and will call with any reoccurrence or change. If needed, an EGD can be scheduled to evaluate her esophagus and stomach.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CC:

Evaluation of Smith-Magenis Syndrome in a 22-month-old patient.

HPI:

Katherine is a 22-month-old female, born at 34 weeks and 3 days, who presents today for an evaluation of Smith-Magenis Syndrome. She has a history of feeding difficulties, reflux, and developmental delays. She is currently in feeding therapy, occupational therapy, physical therapy, and will soon start speech therapy. She has seen multiple specialists, including a geneticist, orthopedic, ophthalmologist, and audiologist.

FAMILY HISTORY:

No family history of kidney failure, dialysis, or transplant.

EXAM:

Physical examination shows a well-nourished female who is slightly fussy when examined. Eyes are small appearing. She has mild hypotonia of the lower extremities in her arms. Normal external female genitalia.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN:

Katherine is a 22-month-old former 34 and 3-week-old, twin with Smith-Magenis Syndrome. Several organ systems can be affected by this chromosomal deletion syndrome. Congenital anomalies of the kidney and urinary tract have been reported in the literature.

We will obtain a screening of the kidneys by ultrasound today. If there are abnormalities on the kidney ultrasound, we will determine next steps and future follow-up. The family lives in Dallas, Georgia, so her follow-up should be at the town center location.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Right wrist injury after a fall.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Patient reports slipping while carrying a laundry basket and falling on her right wrist. The injury occurred yesterday morning. She has been experiencing severe pain (9/10) and swelling in the wrist. She has tried ice, an ACE wrap, and ibuprofen with minimal relief.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

No prior injuries to the right arm.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Head and Neck: No adenopathy, thyromegaly, or carotid bruit.
Cardiovascular: No murmur, rub, or gallop.
Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Extremities: Palpable pulses, no lower edema. Right wrist with obvious swelling, ecchymosis, and tenderness on palpation. Pain on flexion, extension, abduction, and adduction. Limited ability to make a fist.

VITALS

Blood Pressure: 140/70 mmHg
Temperature: 97.2 degrees F
Heart Rate: 80 bpm
Respiratory Rate: 20 breaths/min

RESULTS
Imaging

X-ray of the right wrist: Positive for a Colles' fracture.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Colles' fracture of the right wrist.
- Medical Treatment: Apply a brace to immobilize the wrist. Schedule surgery as soon as possible. Prescribe Ultram 50 mg every 6 hours for pain management. Plan for physical therapy post-surgery.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Informed the patient about the need for surgery and the expected recovery timeline. Advised the patient to follow up in one month to assess progress and discuss vacation plans.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in one month.

CC:

Right knee pain.

HPI:

Mr. Philip is a patient with a past medical history of hypertension who presents today for an evaluation of right knee pain. He states he was working on his property and slipped and fell, resulting in knee pain. He reports feeling a pop during the fall and has experienced swelling. He has been taking ibuprofen for the swelling. He rates his pain as 4/10 when moving. The injury occurred one week ago. He is currently on 20 mg of Lisinopril for hypertension.

EXAM:

Examination of the right knee shows tenderness to the medial aspect and pain with flexion and extension. There is edema around the knee and some effusion. Lungs are clear bilaterally, and a grade 2/6 systolic ejection murmur is noted on the heart exam. X-rays of the right knee show no fractures or bony abnormalities.

IMPRESSION:

1. Right knee MCL strain.
2. Hypertension.

PLAN:

1. For the right knee MCL strain, I have prescribed ibuprofen 800 mg twice a day to help with swelling and pain. I will also provide a knee brace for support and recommend icing the knee for 20 minutes at a time, 3-4 times a day. The patient is advised to elevate and stay off the leg as much as possible.
2. For hypertension, the patient will continue on 20 mg of Lisinopril. I will refer the patient to a nutritionist to help with dietary changes and sodium reduction. The patient will follow up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left shoulder pain.

MEDICAL HISTORY

The patient has been experiencing left shoulder pain for about three weeks. No specific injury can be recalled, but the patient has been active and doing work in their basement.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Musculoskeletal: Reports left shoulder pain, difficulty reaching for objects, and increased pain when laying on the shoulder.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Musculoskeletal
- Examination of the left shoulder: Limited active and passive range of motion.
- Palpation: Tenderness of the greater tuberosity of the humerus, no tenderness at the sternoclavicular or acromioclavicular joints.
- Hand grips: Good.

Neurovascular
- Capillary refill: Less than three seconds.
- Sensation: Intact to light touch.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Left shoulder pain.
- Medical Reasoning: Symptoms are most likely due to rotator cuff tendinopathy, possibly from recent physical activity.
- Additional Testing: Ordering an MRI for the left shoulder to rule out any other issues.
- Medical Treatment: Referring the patient to physical therapy for approximately six to eight weeks. The patient may continue taking Tylenol for pain relief. If symptoms do not improve, a steroid injection for the shoulder may be considered.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Left knee pain.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Andrea is a pleasant patient who presents with occasional left knee pain that occurs less than once a day while walking. The pain is described as internal and affecting the whole kneecap. The patient denies any popping sensation or history of injury to the knee. The pain is not severe enough to require medication and does not interfere with daily activities. However, the patient is concerned about participating in line dancing during an upcoming trip due to the knee pain.

PAST HISTORY

Medical
Hypertension.
Diabetes mellitus.

Surgical
None reported.

SOCIAL HISTORY

Patient enjoys traveling and line dancing.

FAMILY HISTORY

Not reported.

MEDICATIONS

Lisinopril.
Amlodipine.
Hydrochlorothiazide.
Farxiga.
Metformin.

ALLERGIES

None reported.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital signs: Temperature 98.2, Pulse 72, Respirations 16, Blood Pressure 122/70.
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, 2/6 systolic ejection murmur at left base.
Pulmonary: Clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Musculoskeletal: Left knee exam - no ecchymosis, edema, effusion, or pain to palpation. No decreased range of motion. Negative varus and valgus test.

RESULTS

Left knee X-ray: No evidence of fracture or bony abnormality.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Left knee pain: Suspected arthritis. Prescribe meloxicam 15 mg daily and consider physical therapy to strengthen muscles around the knee.
2. Hypertension: Continue lisinopril 20 mg daily. Order echocardiogram to evaluate heart murmur.
3. Diabetes mellitus: Order hemoglobin A1C and lipid panel to assess potential adjustments to metformin dosage.

The patient was informed of the plan and had no further questions. The nurse will schedule the echocardiogram.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Stage three non-small cell lung cancer, cough, and sore throat.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

Beverly is a 53-year-old female with a recent diagnosis of stage three non-small cell lung cancer who presents for follow-up during neo-adjuvant chemotherapy. She was diagnosed with a 4.4 cm left upper lobe nodule. Biopsy was positive for adenocarcinoma, and molecular testing is pending. The patient reports a minimal cough, sore throat, and mild fatigue. She denies any nausea, vomiting, or shortness of breath. The patient has good family support and feels supported by the nursing staff.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Respiratory: Reports minimal cough and sore throat. Denies shortness of breath.
Gastrointestinal: Denies nausea or vomiting. Reports decreased appetite.
General: Reports mild fatigue.

VITALS

All vital signs are within normal limits, including oxygen saturation.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Neck: No cervical lymphadenopathy or supraclavicular adenopathy.
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Respiratory: Crackles bilaterally in lungs.
Skin: Erythema on the anterior left side of the chest, likely related to radiation.
Extremities: No edema.

RESULTS

Chest x-ray: Mild radiation pneumonitis.

ASSESSMENT

1. Stage three non-small cell lung cancer.
2. Radiation pneumonitis.
3. Painful swallowing.

PLAN

1. Continue current chemotherapy regimen (cisplatin and etoposide) and radiation at 45 Gy. Repeat imaging after completion and consider surgical removal of the tumor.
2. Prescribe low-dose prednisone (40 mg daily for 5 days) to reduce inflammation and improve cough and shortness of breath.
3. Prescribe lidocaine swish and swallow (four times a day) to alleviate painful swallowing and promote adequate food and fluid intake.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up at her next scheduled visit.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Abnormal lab work - low immunoglobulin A level.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient reports being referred by their primary care physician due to a low immunoglobulin A level found during a recent physical examination. The patient has a history of frequent colds during the winter season, which tend to linger for a long time. No history of frequent abdominal infections or diarrhea. The patient was recently diagnosed with type 2 diabetes and started on metformin.

PAST MEDICAL HISTORY

Type 2 diabetes.

FAMILY HISTORY

No known family history of immune deficiencies.

SOCIAL HISTORY

The patient's family owns a donut shop.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

No fever or other concerning symptoms.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vitals: Stable, no fever.
Heart: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs.
Lungs: Clear, no wheezes, rales, or rhonchi.
Neck: No lymphadenopathy.
Abdomen: Soft, non-tender, no abnormalities.

LABORATORY DATA

Low immunoglobulin A level.

ASSESSMENT

1. Low immunoglobulin A level - possible IgA deficiency.
2. Type 2 diabetes.

PLAN

1. Order additional blood work to check for other immunodeficiencies.
2. Monitor for any changes in infection frequency or severity, or any changes in the abdominal tract.
3. Instruct the patient to inform healthcare providers of their IgA deficiency if they require blood products in the future.
4. Continue metformin for type 2 diabetes management.
5. Follow up after lab results are available.

INSTRUCTIONS

1. Get lab work done as ordered.
2. Monitor for any changes in infection frequency or severity, or any changes in the abdominal tract.
3. Inform healthcare providers of IgA deficiency if blood products are needed.
4. Continue metformin for type 2 diabetes management.
5. Follow up after lab results are available.

CC:

Right elbow pain.

HPI:

Mr. Lawrence is a patient who presents today for an evaluation of right elbow pain. He reports that he has been doing a lot of pottery during the pandemic and started to develop elbow pain about a week ago. The pain is located on the inside of his right elbow and can sometimes radiate down into his forearm. He rates his pain as 6/10 and states that it has been affecting his sleep and ability to perform certain activities. He has tried ibuprofen with minimal relief. He denies any history of trauma or previous injury to the right elbow.

EXAM:

Vitals are within normal limits. Examination of the right elbow reveals moderate tenderness over the medial epicondyle. Pain is present with palpation, pronation of the forearm, and resistance against flexion of the wrist. No pain is reported with wrist supination.

RESULTS:

X-rays of the right elbow obtained on today's visit show no fracture or bony abnormality.

IMPRESSION:

Medial epicondylitis (right elbow).

PLAN:

At this point, I discussed the diagnosis and treatment options with the patient. I have recommended the following:

1. Rest the right elbow and wear a sling while awake.
2. Apply ice to the elbow for 20 minutes, three times a day.
3. Take ibuprofen 600 mg every 6 hours with food for one week.
4. Avoid pottery work for the next couple of weeks.

The patient will follow up in one week for re-evaluation. All questions were answered.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Chest pain and shortness of breath.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

David is a patient with a history of hypertension who presents today with chest pain and shortness of breath. He reports falling down while walking outside and experiencing chest pain, which he initially dismissed as heartburn. He also reports some shortness of breath during the incident. He was seen in the emergency department and found to have swelling in his ankles.

The patient admits to not consistently taking his prescribed medications for hypertension (Bumex, Cozaar, and Norvasc) and not following a strict diet, often consuming salty foods like chips.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: Endorses chest pain and shortness of breath.
• Respiratory: Denies difficulty sleeping, endorses shortness of breath with exertion.
• Musculoskeletal: Denies any pain or weakness.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vital Signs: Blood pressure 128/72, other vital signs within normal limits.
• Neck: No jugular venous distention.
• Cardiovascular: 2/6 systolic ejection murmur, stable.
• Respiratory: Lungs clear bilaterally.
• Extremities: Trace edema in lower extremities.

Results:

Echocardiogram from the emergency department shows preserved ejection fraction of 55%, normal diastolic filling, and mild to moderate mitral regurgitation.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

David is a patient with a history of hypertension who presents today with chest pain and shortness of breath.

Congestive heart failure.
• Medical Reasoning: Likely caused by dietary indiscretion and uncontrolled hypertension.
• Medical Treatment: Continue Bumex 2 mg once daily. Consult with a nutritionist for dietary advice. Weigh daily and report weight gain of 3 pounds in 2 days.
• Specialist Referrals: Refer to a nutritionist for dietary counseling.

Hypertension.
• Medical Reasoning: Patient has been noncompliant with medications and diet.
• Additional Testing: Order renal artery ultrasound to rule out any underlying issues.
• Medical Treatment: Continue Cozaar 100 mg daily and Norvasc 5 mg daily. Encourage patient to take medications consistently and follow a low-sodium diet.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow-up as needed.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Sharp pain on the right side of the abdomen below the ribs for the last several days.

MEDICAL HISTORY

Patient reports a history of kidney stones and a family history of kidney stones (father).

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Gastrointestinal: Pain moves from the right side of the abdomen to the lower abdomen and groin. Pain is intermittent and severe. Reports nausea but no vomiting.
Genitourinary: Reports pain during urination and dark-colored urine.

VITALS

Not provided.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Abdomen
- General Examination: No tenderness to palpation, no rebound or guarding, no peritoneal signs.
- CVA Tenderness: Positive on the right flank.

RESULTS

CT scan of the abdomen reveals a 0.5 cm kidney stone located in the proximal right ureter. No evidence of hydronephrosis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Acute nephrolithiasis (kidney stone).
- Medical Reasoning: Patient presents with sharp abdominal pain, pain during urination, and a history of kidney stones. CT scan confirms the presence of a kidney stone in the right ureter.
- Patient Education and Counseling: Instructed the patient to push fluids to help facilitate urination and pass the stone.
- Medical Treatment: Prescribed oxycodone 5 mg every 6-8 hours as needed for pain, to be alternated with Tylenol. Provided a strainer for the patient to use to catch the stone when it passes. Ordered a basic metabolic panel, urinalysis, and urine culture.
- Follow-up: Scheduled a follow-up appointment in 1-2 weeks. If the patient is still experiencing symptoms, further treatment options such as lithotripsy or ureteroscopy will be discussed.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

INSTRUCTIONS

The patient will follow up in 1-2 weeks.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Nonhealing foot ulcer on the right foot.

HISTORY OF PRESENT ILLNESS

The patient is a middle-aged male with a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy who presents with a nonhealing foot ulcer on his right foot. The patient first noticed the ulcer approximately six weeks ago after wearing a tight pair of shoes. The ulcer initially presented as a blister, which later unroofed, revealing thick, soft, and mushy skin with a foul smell and yellow drainage. The patient's primary care physician started him on antibiotics six days ago. The patient has experienced fever, chills, and worsening pain in the affected area. The ulcer has turned black around the edges, and the patient has developed cramping in his calf muscle. The patient also reports a red streak coming up the front part of his ankle along the inside portion of his calf muscle, which is very hot. The patient has been coughing and experiencing shortness of breath.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

• Cardiovascular: No palpitations.
• Respiratory: Endorses cough and shortness of breath.
• Musculoskeletal: Endorses cramping in the calf muscle.
• Integumentary: Endorses nonhealing foot ulcer with foul smell and yellow drainage.
• Endocrine: Endorses diabetes and diabetic neuropathy.

PHYSICAL EXAMINATION

• Vital Signs: Slight fever, otherwise stable.
• Foot Exam: Necrotic wound on the heel, approximately 2x2 cm, sloughing tissue, cellulitis, erythemia, no bony exposure.
• Vascular Exam: Bilateral palpable femoral and popliteal pulses, non-palpable dorsalis pedis and posterior tibial pulses, but present via Doppler.

RESULTS

Right foot x-ray: No evidence of osteomyelitis.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

Nonhealing diabetic foot ulcer.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient presents with a nonhealing foot ulcer with signs of infection and worsening pain. The x-ray shows no evidence of osteomyelitis.
• Medical Treatment: Continue current antibiotic therapy, obtain a culture, and consider changing or adding antibiotics based on culture results. Perform debridement in the office today. Monitor the redness and swelling in the patient's leg. Schedule a follow-up appointment in seven days.

Diabetes management.
• Medical Reasoning: The patient has a history of diabetes and diabetic neuropathy, with a current A1C of 6.7. The patient reports blood sugars have been trending higher in the past few weeks.
• Medical Treatment: Encourage the patient to follow up with their endocrinologist and continue monitoring blood sugars closely, aiming to keep A1C below 7.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.

CHIEF COMPLAINT

Tick bite on right knee.

MEDICAL HISTORY

The patient has a history of hypertension and type 2 diabetes. He has been taking lisinopril for hypertension and metformin for diabetes.

REVIEW OF SYSTEMS

Skin: Reports a tick bite on the right knee with erythema, edema, and a bull's-eye rash.
General: Reports headache and not feeling well since the tick bite.

PHYSICAL EXAM

Vital Signs: Blood pressure 122/70, heart rate 67, temperature 98.4°F.
Cardiovascular: Regular rate and rhythm, no murmurs, rubs, or gallops.
Respiratory: Lungs clear to auscultation bilaterally.
Musculoskeletal: Right knee with erythema, edema, and area of fluctuance over the right patella. Pain to palpation of the right anterior knee. Full range of motion of the right knee.
Skin: Bull's-eye rash over the right knee.

ASSESSMENT AND PLAN

1. Tick bite and possible Lyme disease.
- Medical Reasoning: The presence of a bull's-eye rash and recent tick bite raises concern for Lyme disease.
- Medical Treatment: Start doxycycline 100 mg twice a day for three weeks.
- Additional Testing: Order Lyme titer and Western blot to confirm the diagnosis.

2. Hypertension.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood pressure is well-controlled with lisinopril.
- Medical Treatment: Continue lisinopril 20 mg once a day.
- Additional Testing: Order a lipid panel to assess cholesterol levels.

3. Type 2 diabetes.
- Medical Reasoning: The patient's blood sugars are running in the 120s, indicating good control with metformin.
- Medical Treatment: Continue metformin 1000 mg twice a day.
- Additional Testing: Order a hemoglobin A1c to assess long-term blood sugar control. Order a basic metabolic panel to monitor kidney function.

Patient Agreements: The patient understands and agrees with the recommended medical treatment plan.
